metadata.title: Five Skills They Don’t Teach at Data Science Bootcamp (that will get you hired!) | by Jason Yang | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Five Skills They Don’t Teach at Data Science Bootcamp (that will get you hired!)
metadata.description: It’s no secret that bootcamps don’t fully prepare you for a job in data science. Having gone through my share of data science courses/bootcamps/MOOCs on Udacity, Udemy, Coursera, EdX, and General…

all_paragraphs: It’s no secret that bootcamps don’t fully prepare you for a job in data science. Having gone through my share of data science courses/bootcamps/MOOCs on Udacity, Udemy, Coursera, EdX, and General Assembly, I can attest that no interviewer ever said, “I see on your resume that you took a data science bootcamp, you’re hired.” In fact, none of my interviewers ever mentioned my education from online courses and bootcamps.

The truth is that data science bootcamps aren’t some silver bullet to getting your first job in data science. They’re often marketed as a magical solution that if you spend 4 months in the program, you will learn all that you need to get your first job. In reality, bootcamps are more like launchpads. They’re a great start for transitioning into a data science career.

Drawing from my own personal experience as a data scientist and asking my colleagues in industry, here are five skills that we see most applicants lacking when applying to their first data science job.

You’re probably pointing out that you already know SQL from your courses. That’s why I say intermediate SQL. All data science programs will cover SQL, but they don’t take the time to go in depth on SQL. Remember that 80% of your time will be spent on data wrangling. SQL is part of that 80%, and knowing how to write SQL well will save you lots of time.

Why is SQL so important? In your courses, your data is provided to you as a csv file. In production, your data exists in databases. Knowing how to write efficient SQL queries against multiple tables will allow you to pull your own data.
“SELECT * FROM TABLE” is a telltale sign that you‘re inexperienced.

When working with production databases, tables can have billions of rows and hundreds of columns. SELECT * is a quick way to lockup the resources on your database. If you absolutely need to do SELECT *, please include a limit clause, so that the results can actually be retrieved and displayed.
You should also know how and when to use window functions, self joins, and cross joins. Knowing them will make or break your code when working with billion row databases.

In data science bootcamps, you’re doing everything locally on your laptop. In the wild, everything is hosted in the cloud. Navigating through a company’s cloud infrastructure on AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud is among the first things you’ll do in any tech job.

But how is knowing cloud technologies going to get me hired? Job descriptions sometimes don’t explicitly say AWS. Instead, they reference services and technologies on the cloud like “EMR” and “SageMaker.”

In the job description above, we see that they’re hiring for BigQuery experience. BigQuery is Google Cloud’s serverless data warehouse (Yes, you query it using SQL). From this, you can probably assume that their services are hosted on Google Cloud, and any experience you have with it will automatically make you more hire-able than the next candidate.
In one of our interviews, we asked the candidate, “That’s a good solution, but where do you get the data?”
The answer to “where does the data come from?” is not pd.read_csv()

As a working data scientist, there’s no folder on my desktop that I click open for my data in a csv file. I’m usually working with parquet and gzip files that’s hosted in a cloud bucket or querying a database to retrieve my data. For example, to get the necessary data to answer a business question, I may need to work with several engineers to understand different parts of the process from how it’s generated to how to efficiently pull all the data into one central location for analysis.

In practice, data science is much more messy. Like stochastic gradient descent, we’re iterating towards a solution, but often without good indicators. Something seemingly simple as answering the question “What was sales last month?” can often turn out to be much more complicated as the data can exist across multiple databases and a co-worker’s excel sheet. You’d be surprised how much of data is some excel sheet attachment in email chains.
To gain some real world experience in data science, join in a hackathon, start your own data project, generate your own data, participate in community data events and groups.

Data scientists are often the middle person to data questions. For example, we work between engineers who generate the data and product managers who want to answer some questions with the data. In other words, we work with multiple stakeholders and resources to solve data related questions.

In bootcamps, we’re given problem sets with clear objectives on what’s correct. On the job, success is often not defined, constantly changing at best. This is why it’s important to view the problem in a broader sense and understand what is actually being requested.

We’re not looking for the perfect answer. We’re looking for the best answer that can be deployed on time. In bootcamps, we’re tasked to improve the accuracy of our models. On the job, accuracy is just one of many metrics that we’re trying to achieve. Others include maintain-ability, deploy-ability, scalability, reproducibility, and can we do all that within a limited time frame?

We need to be agile and flexible to changing requests and data. The answer that you were trying to solve at the start of the sprint might change mid-sprint. Case in point: the recent pandemic changed a lot of business operations, including that of data science teams.

The data can change or break. Know that the solutions and models that you built have limited shelf life. Say, the demand-forecast dashboard that you built last month may be outdated/broken because some data that was previously available has changed formats or is no longer available.

As an added bonus, make sure to include continued education in your data science journey. The field is rapidly evolving every year, so you need to continue learning about the latest technology and techniques. All data scientists I know have some side project or hobby that they’re pursuing to improve their data science skills.
